title: US-Mexico border bridge reopens after migrant campout
text:
Desperate migrants from Central American and elsewhere shutdown a bridge connecting the United States and Mexico on Thursday demanding that their asylum requests be processed much quicker.

The Gateway International Bridge, which connects the Mexican city of Matamoros and Brownsville, Texas, was closed at about 1:30am when a group of 250-300 asylum-seeking migrants stretched out along the road, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

Traffic on the busy bridge was closed down for a half-day while the migrants, including babies, stretched out on the road.

The protest also caused long lines to form at other international crossings leading out of Matamoros.

Following a 13-hour shutdown, the migrants left and U.S. authorities reopened the crossing, which handles about 80 percent of the Brownsville-Matamoros pedestrian traffic.

Migrants stage a protest behind a gate on a bridge that connects the Mexican city of Matamoros and Brownsville, Texas

On Thursday, almost 300 asylum-seeking migrants camped out for half the day at a bridge that connects Mexico and the United States after rumors spread that U.S. officials would review asylum requests

A migrant grabs his head as he stands next to the fence closing the Gateway International Bridge that connects downtown Matamoros, Mexico with Brownsville, Texas

The migrants said they were tired of waiting to make their initial asylum requests at the U.S. border crossing.

The group traveled to the bridge amidst rumors that they would be allowed to enter the United States despite the stringent immigration guidelines imposed by the Trump administration, which has forced migrants to wait on the Mexican side of the border for their asylum requests to be considered as part of the 'Remain in Mexico' policy.

'We do not want to block traffic. We just want someone to talk to us, and this was the only way to do it,' said Ernesto Banegas, a 51-year-old construction worker from Honduras who fled his country after his five-year-old son was kidnapped.

Carla Moradel, who was sent back to Mexico after crossing into the United States, said she has been waiting for two months and just wanted officials to say 'yes or no.'

'If they had clearly told me, "No,' I would have gone back to Honduras, but I think there is still a chance,'" said the 21-year-old, who also left Honduras with her 5-year-old son because she couldn't find work.

A Honduran migrants hugs her three-year-old daughter while joining a group of asylum seekers who on Thursday blocked a bridge that connects Mexico and the United States to demand quickness in the asylum process

Migrant women sleep while camping out on the Gateway International Bridge on Thursday after nearly 300 asylum seekers showed up demanding their requests to be reviewed by U.S. immigration agents

Under a policy known as metering, U.S. officials at many border bridges accept only a few asylum-seekers a day. The Associated Press found about 19,000 names on waiting lists in four border cities visited in late July.

Frustration with U.S. policies aimed at limiting asylum requests has sparked mass attempts to cross border entries before. But Thursday's camp-out on the Mexican side of the Matamoros bridge appeared to be more of a protest than an attempt to cross.

In the afternoon, Matamoros Mayor Mario Alberto López walked onto the bridge to talk to the migrants and try to convince them to reopen the span.

Migrants told the mayor they were living in dirty conditions in Matamoros with little shelter or access to toilets, and he promised to send cleaning crews and set up washing facilities.

Seguismundo Doguín, National Immigration Institute delegate in Tamaulipas, said the protesters' demands were heard and relayed to U.S. officials, and that the migrants at the bridge were offered to be taken in at a shelter to await their court dates in better conditions.

A one-year-old Mexican girl sits on the Gateway International Bridge during migrant protests

Stringent immigration guidelines placed by the Trump administration has forced migrants to wait on the Mexican side of the border for their asylum requests to be considered as part of the 'Remain in Mexico' policy

Migrant children play with a traffic cone as U.S. Customs and Border Protection agents look on from afar at the Gateway International Bridge

The migrants cleared the roadbed of the bridge and remained blocking the sidewalk portion.

But López and others pointed out that the blockade had caused inconveniences for Matamoros residents who need to cross for work, shopping or other reasons.

Liliana Ramírez, 35, who sells flavored shaved ice to crossing pedestrians, said it was a lost day with zero sales.

Such protests 'harm everyone,' Ramírez said. 'Also (the migrants) - things are going to be made more difficult for them.'

She also complained about trash left at the camp.

Orlando Valerio, a 53-year-old Nicaraguan migrant, said he missed his asylum hearing appointment because of the protest.

A migrant mother and child were among 250-300 people who blocked off a bridge connecting Mexico and the United States in an attempt to have their asylum requests processed

Migrants grew tired of waiting to make their initial asylum requests at the U.S. border crossing and forced the shutdown of the busy Gateway International Bridge

'I understand them, I am one of them,' Valerio said. 'But they can't block things this way.'

The CBP statement said migrants who had been returned to Mexico to wait for hearings on their asylum cases [a policy known as MPP, or Migrant Protection Protocol], but who could not cross due to the closure would be given new dates.

Some locals were sympathetic to the migrants.

Francisco Tovar, who plays piano at a bar near the border, said people could have crossed elsewhere.

'These are political questions, and the United States and Mexico have to do something,' he said.

Moments after traffic resumed Thursday, U.S. border patrol agents staged one of their regular anti-riot exercises. Smoke canisters were fired and the crossing was closed again, though this time for just a couple of minutes.
description: Desperate migrants from Central American and elsewhere shutdown a bridge connecting the United States and Mexico on Thursday to demand asylum from the Trump administration.
